comments:
A customer ran into some problems when trying to disable a plug-in.

After installing the plug-in, the customer attempted to return to the pre-plug-
in state. The customer went into the configuration list, found the plug-in, 
selected it, and clicked the "Disable" button. This acted as if it disabled the 
plug-in, but it didn't (The plug-in behavior still exists). The customer also
noted that the configuration still has the date it obtained from the plug-in. 
So, now the customer has a configuration that claims it doesn't have the plug-
in, but it actually does.

If the customer selects the latest configuration in the Configuration History 
and tries to "revert" to the one with the new plug-in, the customer gets the 
following error:

Unable to complete action for feature "<plug-in name>" due to errors. Internal 
Error. The Feature "<feature name>" does not have a content consumer.

It appears that once this plug-in is installed, it is there to stay. This
is true whether it shows the plug-in as enabled or disabled. 

Is this an Eclipse problem or a problem with the plug-in?  Here is the stack:


!STACK 1
org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Internal Error. The Feature "<feature 
name>" does not have a content consumer.

Did the customer restart the workbench after disabling the plugin (more 
precisely, the feature) ?
Do you have a test case? Is the problem reproduceable on 3.0 or 3.1 drivers ?

Yes, the customer did restart the workbench. I reproduced what he is seeing, 
and I also restarted the workbench.

My testcase involved WSDD 5.7.1 and an iFix. This is built on 2.1.2, so I don't 
have 3.0 drivers for testing.

Shall I email this testcase to you with instructions?

Thanks.
Is this a must fix bug or can the customer work around the issue?
Given that we're working on the 3.1 stream, and 3.0.x is already out, it is 
unlikely that there will be more fixes on the eclipse 2.1.x stream.
Yes, you can attach the testcase, and it would be even better if you can 
provide a similar scenario on a plain eclipse driver.

You can close this. It turns out that the iFix had the wrong install handler in 
it.

traces.message: Internal Error. The Feature "<feature  name>" does not have a content consumer.
